awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for the 2019 International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA)
awd_abstract_narration:
The 11th International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) 2019 takes place in Cambridge UK July 8th to July 12th and will bring together researchers from electronic design automation (the practice of using computer software to build complex electronics) and synthetic biology (the forward design of novel biological systems using engineering principles). The goal of IWBDA is to make biology more easily, robustly, reliably, and predictably engineered and therefore, tackle challenges in biology and medicine, leading to advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention. This award provides travel assistance for ten undergraduate and graduate students to attend this workshop to present research, participate in a computer programming competition, and network with a large community of industrial and academic researchers. These participants will go on to form the foundation of the field in the future.
	
Specifically these students will join a wide variety of researchers (120+) from electronic design automation and synthetic biology in a unique context which does not exist elsewhere. They will have access to between twelve and fifteen technical talks, two invited lectures, ten to twenty posters, multiple group discussion sessions, and a featured student programming competition (BDAthlon). This award covers the registration for the workshop as well as partial support for travel and housing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2019 International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) was held July 8th to July 10th 2019 at Cambridge University in the UK.  IWBDA brought together researchers from electronic design automation (the practice of using computer software to build complex electronics) and synthetic biology (the forward design of novel biological systems using engineering principles).  The goal of IWBDA is to make biology more easily, robustly, reliably, and predictably engineered and therefore, tackle challenges in biology and medicine, leading to advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.  There were a total of more than 100 participants from major research universities and industry. Approximately half of the participants were graduate student researchers.  In addition to NSF sponsorship, industrial participation was also a key contributor to the quality of the workshop and related discussions. Industrial sponsors included: Raytheon BBN Technologies and Lattice Automation. 


This workshop had six technical talk sessions: Design Automation, Machine Learning, Computation in Genetic Circuits, Modeling, Data Standards and Visulization, and Microfluidics. In these sessions there were a total of 19, 20 minute talks selected from peer-reviewed, extended abstracts. These abstracts are archived on the website program. In addition, there were two keynote speakers. They were Dr. Traci Haddock-Angelli from the iGEM Foundation ("Setting Standards in Synthetic Biology") and Prof. Luca Cardelli from Oxford University ("Integrated Scientific Modeling and Lab Automation").  There were 12 posters presented and a whole group discussion session. ACS Synthetic Biology used submissions as part of a "special issue" highlighting the technical contributions of the workshop.

For more information please see: http://www.iwbdaconf.org/2019/
